title: 113_hr4962
content: The "National Border and Homeland Security Act" establishes priority distributions under the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program, giving priority to states on the northern or southern border and political subdivisions with large populations of unlawfully present aliens. SEC. 3. FENCING ALONG AND OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE SOUTHWEST BORDER. Amendments are made to the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 and the Secure Fence Act of 2006 regarding fencing and operational control along the Southwest border. Amendments are made to the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 and the Secure Fence Act of 2006 regarding fencing and operational control along the Southwest border. The changes include setting a deadline of December 31, 2015, for implementation and requiring consultation with State and local officials along the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to increase the number of full-time Border Patrol agents for fiscal years 2015 to 2018, with deployments to both the southern and northern borders. In fiscal years 2015-2018, the Secretary of Homeland Security must increase the number of Customs and Border Protection officers by at least 200 at U.S. ports of entry. Additionally, a biometric entry and exit data system is to be implemented. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish a biometric entry and exit data system at all U.S. ports of entry within 18 months. Additionally, there is a prohibition on impeding certain activities related to border security. On public lands in the United States, the Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture cannot hinder Homeland Security's activities for operational control. Additionally, there is a section on global nuclear detection architecture. Section 1902(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to develop objectives, roles, responsibilities, funding, and monitoring mechanisms for carrying out activities related to potential smuggling routes in land border areas, railcars entering the US from Canada or Mexico, and private aircraft or small vessels. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to develop objectives, roles, responsibilities, funding, and monitoring mechanisms for activities related to potential smuggling routes in land border areas, railcars entering the US from Canada or Mexico, and private aircraft or small vessels. Additionally, paragraph (14) is revised to specify the subsection for certain provisions. The Secretary of Homeland Security must determine and procure next-generation portable radiation detectors and radioactive isotope identification devices for Border Patrol agents within one year of this Act. Additionally, a strategic plan is required to detect and interdict biological and chemical weapons. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to develop a strategic plan to detect and interdict biological and chemical weapons entering the United States within one year of this Act. Implementation of the Plan must be completed within two years. Reports to Congress detailing the Plan are required within specified timelines. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit reports to Congress annually on the implementation of the strategic plan to detect and interdict biological and chemical weapons entering the United States.
